My guess as to why strange matter (if it existed during the Big Bang) didn’t take over the universe is that:

1. The 4 main forces, like the nuclear forces, didn’t exist at the very first moment, so matter could not exist at all, in any fashion, including strange matter.

2. At the beginning of the universe, quarks were too evenly spaced to be able to bond to one set over another.

3. There were too many unstable forms of quarks in the early universe for any group of stable quarks to be able to group together into a perfectly stable state.

4. If strange matter did exist in the early universe, Cosmic Inflation would have likely ripped any matter apart to the point where nothing could bond together in open space to the point that it could create quark matter.

if strange mater actually exists, it would have to be negatively charged (which is highly unlikely because it would most likely be positively charged, and since most matter (on earth at least) is positively charged the matter on earth would repel the strange matter), it would also have to be able to exist in the pressure of the vacuum of space and the pressure of earths atmosphere, and strange matter would also have to be more stable than any other matter for it to be able to "infect" earth and/or any other planet or star. so its verry unlikely that strange matter would be infectious if it even exist at all outside neutron stars (which if a neutron star's core was made of strange matter, it might actually consume the star from the inside and convert it into a "strange star" regardless of if it can "infect" things in the vacuum of space because of the immense pressures at the core of neutron stars, but we really do not know for sure). and most Physicist conclusively disagree that "strange matter/strangelets" where made after the first microsecond of the big bang for a number of different reason that are to complex for a YouTube chat LOL.

Advanced civilizations would likely seek to repoint the pulsar GRB kilonova event towards a lower populated part of the universe. It is almost like repointing a loaded gun that is going off to an unpopulated part of the universe.

How to do this. Model a GRB kilonova event impact on surrounding systems. Then model the same event versus all other directions. See which directions impact the most neighborhood systems. It is likely that the actual location of a previous GRB kilonova event is probably the direction that impacts the fewest neighborhood systems. Compared to other directions, we would probably see that the direction minimizes the neighborhood impact.

Why would we expect to see this?

The kilonova event is among the most sudden and "life destructive" events in the universe.

Advanced civilizations should be able to:
0. Observe a kilonova when it happens. (This is where humans are currently).
1. Detect a future kilonova in advance. (This is in the future for humans).
2. Predict the kilonova event dates in advance. (20+ years from now for us)
3. Influence a kilonova event in advance. (500+ years from now)
4. Prevent a kilonova event in advance. (5000+ years from now)

.
It is very likely that advanced civilizations will be able to influence or prevent a kilonova, which is #3 and #4. Similar to asteroid detection, our future ancestors will seek to manage the risk associated with this.
.
Why is this important?
Because we can observe the kilonovas and the impact of the same.
If civilizations can observe the impact of a kilonova, it is likely that the direction it is pointed will influence the fewest number of inhabitable star systems.

If we could determine the direction/impact of the kilonova and we modeled this versus all possibilities, we should see that the actual impact minimizes the impact on other solar systems and areas. If we have highly evolved life in the universe, they would likely seek to reduce the impact of one of these events. And we would see that the kilonova event is pointed in a direction which minimizes the impact to another part of the universe. It is almost like repointing a loaded gun that is going off to an unpopulated part of the universe.

Thus strange matter can only exist in a neutron star.  If released it will convert to ordinary 1st generation matter.

Note: The reason that something like Strange Matter would cause other forms of matter to Decay into Strange Matter is this. All matter and particles in the universe seek to reach a state of Stability, or basically, the lowest form that they can take. That's why Atoms eventually "Decay" into smaller atoms, the "Half-Life" of an atom is this process, the process in which the Atom will decay into a more stable form or into it's subatomic pieces. If Strange Matter existed and it was the Lowest and Most Stable state of Matter possible, it's entirely plausible that other materials that make contact with it will spontaneous release extreme amounts of energy(since you can't just have crap ton of atoms break apart into quarks without some sort of consequence) and then also become Strange Matter.

Energy State's and the Need for the universe to be Stable and at it's Lowest Energy State has other implications. Like, in certain theories of Quantum Physics where the Higgs Field(Yes entire Fields such as the Gluon Field that allows Quarks to exist, seek to be at their lowest energy state as well.) is not at it's Lowest Energy State. What this would mean is that if at any point through Quantum Tunneling or some sort of incredible event that makes lots of Energy, the Higgs Field would jump down an energy state and as a result if a Fundamental Field of Nature jumps down an Energy State, the entire universe has to change with it. So, a sphere of all consuming destruction would expand out through space at the Speed of Light in an attempt to change everything to the same energy state as that one region of space. We wouldn't be able to see it coming. We would have no idea that this happened. And it will kill us all instantly.

Neutrons have a huge influence on nuclear behavior and property, but they are unstable by themselves. Why couldn't the same be true for strange matter? If we can theorize that neutron stars get weird on the inside and possibly break down all matter into one giant glob, then wouldn't it be reasonable to think that this is possibly how the big bang began. Or, possibly how life began. I don't think that this logic applies to only Earth. I believe that there are other life forms under different living conditions, surviving different environments. They must hold the key to understanding the universe as well, no? It would make sense to study ourselves further as there is much we do not know about our own species nonetheless our own planet. I think in our DNA lies the material to creating all life, as seen from our ability to reproduce, and with that DNA we can better understand how life can exist in different environments. But, one does wonder if this is all just a simulation. One cosmic joke after the other. I think in order to understand, we must learn, and in order to learn we need knowledge. To hold knowledge above all else means we would shed ourselves of mortality. Ideology is not science, it is a shared belief or one's own belief. To gain knowledge means we need to learn more about ourselves. When you look outside the world, you might not understand what lies beyond, because maybe everything we need to know is right here.

Strange quarks are unstable (extremely short half-life) so they are no risk to anyone. They exist in the core of neutron star only due to availability of extreme energy in the core of a neutron star. Once outside, they decay into down-quarks, which merge with up-quarks to form ordinary neutrons. If the neutrons don't collide and fuse with protons, they decay (15 min half life) into hydrogen atom (proton electron pair) and merge into the inter-stellar gas/dust made of the same material. Strange stars are wonderful only inside the core of stars. Once outside, all "strangeness" is gone in no time.

After watching this video I went and did a bit of research and I found out something about strange matter.

Strangelets, over time, will decay to their ground state and become positively charged, and if it's charge is positive the conversion will not happen. This is because all atomic nuclei have a positive charge, so a strangelet would be electrostaticly repelled and never make direct contact with the nuclei, which is required for the conversion to start. (Also electrons are not affected because they are leptons and can not decay into quarks.)

This sounds very sci-fi like. Strange quarks are not stable without sufficient gravity and decay into down quarks. If this down quark does not combine with 2 up quarks (becomes a proton), or an up and a down quark (becomes a neutron), or an anti-down (very unlikely, becomes a meson) they further decay into an up quark.
So, don't fear that strange matter would hit the earth, It decays way before it would reach us.

So this video is basically BS. If you follow the sources, there's a paper about strangelets converting ordinary matter, and in the abstract it says:


"We discuss in most detail the possibility of producing a dangerous strangelet. We argue that four separate requirements are necessary for this to occur:existence of large stable strangelets, metastability of intermediate size strangelets, negative charge for strangelets along the stability line, and production of intermediate size strangelets in the heavy ion environment. We discuss both theoretical and experimental reasons why each of these appears unlikely; in particular, we know of no plausible suggestion for why the third or especially the fourth might be true. Given minimal physical assumptions the continued existence of the Moon, in the form we know it, despite billions of years of cosmic ray exposure, provides powerful empirical evidence against the possibility of dangerous strangelet production."

So the video's own source argues that it's extremely unlikely dangerous strangelets exist. Now I'm wondering if the rest of this channel's videos are all clickbait bullcrap too.

The properties that you say that strange matter most likely has match the theoretical properties of a singularity. Infinite density? Indestructibility?

Also, we know due to the laws of physics that if there was strange matter at the core of neutron stars, then the whole star would instantly be converted to strange matter, so we can already conclude that strange matter is not at the core of a neutron star.

We also know that neutron stars are not black holes due to the electromagnetic forces that cause molecules to repel each other, which further supports the conclusion that strange matter is not at the core of neutron stars.

Furthermore, if my theory that singularities are the only place in the universe where strange matter exists and is stable is taken into account, it would explain the lack of planets collapsing due to your theorised "strangelets".

So, for those looking for a reason not to fear strangelets, or those who didn't read the full comment :

Stranglets most likely don't exist, as the only place where strange matter can exist stably is under the infinite gravitational pressure of a black hole.

Just for anyone who's worried about this, I've done some research into the topic just to see how true it all is. Strange quarks are far more massive than up and down quarks, so they could only actually convert these quarks into strange quarks if the collisions were at high energies, which aren't extremely common, and it can't be ignored that strange matter itself has yet to be proven outside of theoretics, as claimed in some of the sources this video actually uses, and if it were anywhere near as "infectious" as claimed here, we would surely see evidence of it in many stars which would no longer be able to produce fusion in their cores and therefore the high energy gamma rays that are produced during the process, as well as being far smaller and denser than they ought to be, however we just simply don't find it. While it may exist in the cores of neutron stars, it has been shown that they aren't stable under more regular pressures such as the LHC where strange particles have briefly been created before decaying into other quarks and, of course, outer space. Its an interesting topic, but maybe keep the existential dread for where its actually valid?

Hey, I study physics in Brussels and I'm reading a few scientific articles on the subject. In particular, it's been 35 years we know strangelets are not dangerous whatsoever. Here it is, supported by all background and calculations you might want to check :

"If quark matter with strangeness is bound, then energetically it can grow indefinitely by absorbing nucleons. On might at first think that quark matter would be dangerous in contact with ordinary matter, but this is not the case. [...] To balance the chemical potential difference, there will be an almost equal electrostatic potential of +50MeV at the surface of (and throughout) a nugget of quark matter, this potential will be more than adequate to repel positively charged nuclei at ordinary temperatures or at reasonably low velocities. Quark matter is in this respect no more dangerous than oxygen." Edward Witten, "Cosmic separation of phases", Physical Review D,1984

Also, I have checked your source for your "end of the world" theory - your source EXPLICITELY says the scenario is unlikely because it would mean having negatively charged strangelets. Once again I'm a bit disappointed by the way you guys transmit scientific information.

Quark should rhyme with quart, not fart. From Murray Gell-Mann "The Quark and the Jaguar": "In 1963, when I assigned the name "quark" to the fundamental constituents of the nucleon, I had the sound first, without the spelling, which could have been "kwork". Then, in one of my occasional perusals of Finnegans Wake, by James Joyce, I came across the word "quark" in the phrase "Three quarks for Muster Mark". Since "quark" (meaning, for one thing, the cry of the gull) was clearly intended to rhyme with "Mark", as well as "bark" and other such words, I had to find an excuse to pronounce it as "kwork". But the book represents the dream of a publican named Humphrey Chimpden Earwicker. Words in the text are typically drawn from several sources at once, like the "portmanteau" words in "Through the Looking-Glass". From time to time, phrases occur in the book that are partially determined by calls for drinks at the bar. I argued, therefore, that perhaps one of the multiple sources of the cry "Three quarks for Muster Mark" might be "Three quarts for Mister Mark", in which case the pronunciation "kwork" would not be totally unjustified. It should probably be noted that this videos topic is hypothetical in every sense of the word. There has been no observational confirmation of stable stranglets, and current observations seem to favor the idea that neutron stars (or at least their surfaces) are comprised of regular, nuclear matter. Cool video, and a good treatment of a speculative and interesting theory, but you should probably make it more clear that this is more of an astrophysical curiosity than anything else right now.

This idea of strange matter is bogus and crap. Its completely false. strange quarks and charm quarks make up mu matter which is denser then L matter which is composed of up and down quarks. mu matter decays in our space, or I should say strange quarks and charm quarks decay into up and down quarks. The idea that strange matter would be stable outside of a neutron star if it even exists at all is stupid. And its even stupider to think that it will convert L matter into this stupid strange matter that you made up. It wont and never will. if anything the moment its not under that much pressure from the neutron star it will explode converting into light and L matter. and even if it was stable, if it were to contact L matter, it would pass straight threw it due to the quarks not being bound together and producing a proper magnetic field(you know, the electric repulsion that stops to atoms from being in the same place. Also if it could contact it, it would not destroy it or convert it. The only thing it might do is attract it gravitationaly. And frankly everything you said is stupid and makes no sense.

Even if you take into account the idea of the particles never interacting inside a neutron star, well, uh, that doesn’t back this up at all. Strange quarks would make up the entire core of a neutron star, right? So, even if it’s rare, it’s near 100% certain that at some point, particles are going to interact with others. And even then, these negligible distances happen all of the time with regular matter, in fact that’s the norm; electrons can’t interact with each other normally due to having the same polarization, yet atoms can still interact with other atoms. Therefor, strange matter shouldn’t be able to do this, or else every neutron star would be like this.

As an actual astrophysics major let me give this a quick reality check. A-If strangelets have the properties assumed here, and are stable outside of neutron star cores, then they would have converted the entire neutron star into strange matter including its surface. Observational evidence from the neutron star merger observed in August of 2017 indicates that normal matter (heavy elements such as Gold) was created in the merger and subsequent explosion, and if neutron stars were made of strange matter, this would not have been observed. And elements made in neutron star mergers exist on Earth so these strangelets would have been present at some point before, during, or after Earth's formation, and we are all here, so, probably zero danger of us all being turned into strange matter.

ordinary nuclei have been dubbed “strangelets”. Strange matter may exist in the
cores of neutron stars, where it is stabilized by intense pressure.
For strange matter to pose a hazard at a heavy ion collider, four conditions would
have to be met:
• Strange matter would have to be absolutely stable in bulk at zero external
pressure. If strange matter is not stable, it will not form spontaneously.
• Strangelets would have to be at least metastable for very small atomic mass, for
only very small strangelets can conceivably be created in heavy ion collisions.
• It must be possible to produce such a small, metastable strangelet in a heavy
ion collision.
• The stable composition of a strangelet must be negatively charged. Positively
charged strangelets pose no threat whatsoever."

This paper goes on to talk about how unlikely this situation is many times over. This video does not do a good enough job at truly describing how vastly unlikely this situation is and is fear mongering exclusively for views.

“In such a scenario, the region of high-temperature phase behaves like a leaky balloon, unable to support itself against outside pressure because of steady neutrino losses. The balloon shrinks, losing neutrinos without losing baryons; the shrinking balloon does not build up a pressure excess because excess qq pairs annihilate into neutrinos, which escape. The baryon excess is continually concentrated in a smaller volume. There is a rich element of wishful thinking here, since this picture assumes neutrino losses are the main way for the high-temperature phase to lose energy, while in fact neutrino losses and surface evaporation appear comparable. However, this scenario is worth exploring because—as we will see—it leads to fascinating consequences.”

Cosmology, the Sci-Fi of science. You can say anything you want,  makeup any theory you want and change it like changing the channel on a television. Nothing is testable, everything has already happened, everything is at an enormous distance and actual distance is debatable. Events are unpredictable and infrequent with enormous gaps of time between them. We're not sure time even works the same out there, everywhere. There seems to be as many theories as they are stars. For example, there's a great deal of argument whether a star is gaseous or liquid in nature and that makes an enormous difference in how it behaves. Metallic hydrogen present? My vote is star is liquid in nature,( I've seen strong evidence for this) and my statement is neither valid or invalid. I understand we have to look at these things and wander but let's be upfront with the public, it's like pulling a rabbit out of your hat, mostly guesswork and alot speculation. Letting your imagination run away with you can be a lot of fun and interesting so I said go for it but be honest. Cosmological theories are literally way out there.😀

To those worried, don't worry too much. He neglects to note that the dangerous kind of strangelet (aside from requiring the hypothesis of their existence to be true in the first place) requires that the strangelet be above a certain size AND negatively charged.

Strange matter should in theory be typically made out of an average of 2 (-1/3) charge quarks (one of which is the strange quark) and 1 (+2/3) charge quark. Accomplishing negative charges on a sufficiently large piece of it is, suffice to say, not that likely.

Assuming that there IS a chance for the "ice-9" scenario he suggests, then it is exceedingly uncommon, as we have had almost 5 billion years with a target whose cross section is about equal to that of the Sun and our planets/moons, and not one of them has gotten "strange-ified."

If there had been a "strange incident" with any notable planet or moon other than Earth and the Sun (since at the very least, we would not be here if either of those were hit), then we would notice the discrepency between how the planets and their moons are acting, and how they SHOULD be reacting based on how much gravity each of those things should have assuming it to be made of normal baryonic matter.

Again, all this assumes that the hypothesis about strange matter being able to be stable is true. The strange quark itself is more stable than a quark of its mass "should" be, but it is still fairly unstable relative to normal ones.

Thankfully, there is little evidence that this stuff actually exists (or if it exists, there's no evidence that it converts everything it touches). In fact, there is some evidence to the contrary considering that all of the measurements we've received from what we assume to be neutron stars indicates an at least partial composition of nuclei, instead of a surface of strange matter. That being the case, it's quite likely that strange matter doesn't actually immediately convert the surrounding matter to itself, and, under lower pressures, would actually simply decay back into up and down quark matter.

To everyone taking this seriously, don't.
Even the articles cited in the description make assumptions on how these particles work, and for the most part the video talks about a type of stranglet that apparently isn't even stable or probable to make.
The stable version of a strangelet is positive. According to the sources these pose no threat as they protect themselves from reaction. Negative ones are the ones that are the threat.
Even then the paper "Review of Speculative "Disaster Scenarios" at RHIC, 2000" doesn't seem to full explain why a strangelet would convert standard matter to strange matter indefinitely. Just sorta says it would. Perhaps I missed it, but I couldn't find anything.

So in short: This video is basically a scientific conspiracy theory. Its a theory on papers the make theories based on assumptions.

I get your meaning, but I don’t think we should say anything can “break the rules” of Nature,
since natural laws are descriptive, not prescriptive like legal laws.

Anything that happens in reality must be naturally possible... so it’s up to us to fit that into our Descriptive scientific laws about the nature of our universe.

For many people this will seem like an obvious point once reminded, but also there’s so much public confusion about these things for many others, that I think the semantics matter. :)

When I was in middle school I had an idea of a weapon capable of destroying the universe through being so energetic it produced particles with enough energy to break apart subatomic particles which would then have enough energy to break apart more subatomic particles and so on. While I now know that it (probably) wouldn’t work like that as it would take more energy to break apart even most atoms (let alone protons and neutrons) than you’d get out of it, but now I know of two methods of destroying the universe that resemble my Middle School idea. Vacuum decay where a single energetic particle causes a light-speed expanding bubble of a universe with new rules along with the corresponding heat shield from all the free energy from transitioning to a lower energy state. And Strange matter which could convert anything it touches into itself, which is arguably even worse as it doesn’t sound like it spews out more of itself so while it won’t destroy the Universe through a chain reaction, it can be used by aliens to destroy any planet they so desire. Perhaps developing this matter and then weaponizing it could be a Great Filter for more advanced civilizations should they colonize multiple planets and learn enough terraforming that ordinary Nuclear weapons no longer pose a Great Filter threat.

Apparently according to RHIC, strangelets only are dangerous if they're negatively charged, which require very particular environments to form, which they might not even have in neutron stars (they require zero net external pressure, which is not the case in neutron stars).

Also given the information here, it seems like maybe a possible reason that negatively charged strangelets that are formed might not regularly interact with matter due to the fact that quark groups remain separate except when they become quark gluon plasma under extreme conditions, so strange quarks may not actually be able to interact with normal matter quark groups unless the entire celestial body that they interact with can replicate subatomic plasma environments.

Speaking as a layman, I think some information here could be better.

As I understand it, whether a star is a neutron star, quark star, or strange star has mostly to do with what type of degenerate matter that the core is made of. Neutron stars have a neutronium core, quark stars have a quark matter core, and strange stars have a strange matter core. You alluded to this with how they may look just like a neutron star, but they point is that they are not that star, so you referring to a strange star as a neutron star isn't quite right.

The other thing is that these have to do with the amount of mass between being a neutron star and being a black hole.

There's a thing called the Pauli exclusion principle which stops certain types of matter from occupying the same region of space at the same energy levels.

At higher masses, atoms lose their bonds and their parts become neutrons in the way you said. Neutrons losing their bonds and becoming quarks also allows these particles to pack more tightly, but requires enough force from gravity, just like with the neutron stars.

What makes strange stars so much denser and closer to being a black hole is that they require so much mass to force some of the quarks into being strange quarks, which allows them to overcome the exclusion principle and occupy even closer regions and thus pack so tightly.

Granted, I'm getting most of that from PBS Space Time, which is also very dumbed down, but I wish at least the star name thing could have been better.

Ok, so. With the high amount of neutron star collisions throughout the universe over its lifetime, the quark-gluon plasma that existed just after the big bang, and the fact that we aren't all strange matter now seems to suggest that strange matter is probably not be as stable at low pressures as its been suggested to be in this video. There is an argument that nominal matter is metastable and COULD decay into strange matter, but that's so far unfounded experimentally, and is largely unfalsifiable due to the very nature of strange matter.
Fear mongering over baseless hypotheses does not promote scientific discourse with the public and imo is the equivalent of religious doomsday prophecy. Vacuum decay, strangelets, and colliding with other universes are typically reductive conversations when trying to increase public interest except with those who enjoy conspiracy theories.

A mistake right from the get go. The universe never "began". That presupposes that something existed prior to the universe which is fundamentally impossible. You should've use the phrase the first moments of the universe instead. The universe has an age, but it never "began". You can call me pedantic, but these types of mistakes create unnecessary paradoxes in people's heads and make metaphysical enlightenment that much harder to attain.

For the source of my claim here, please refer to Charles Tew's video "How to Think About the Universe".

Ok so there’s a huge difference between thermodynamic stability and the kinetics that are really missing from your video. First is that while strange matter is thermodynamically stable, the kinetics of quantum processes cause it to decay by emission of mesons and pions. So any strangelets in the universe that are small will have decayed into cosmic radiation and normal matter. Second that the rate of strange matter conversion is proportional to ke^-Ea/RT where Ea is the activation energy of the baryonic transiton to the strange flavor assuming rate laws of kinetics still apply for this state, small specks of matter would take trillions of years to make a dent in massive objects the size of the earth or  the sun. This is far from a world ending event, heck the sun will consume us before it “takes over” it’s very possible some small amounts of strange matter are slowly growing on the earth in the crust or mantle but ultimately are small and isolated.

Kurzgesagt: False Vacuum Decay
Me: Thanks for that. I always wanted to be aware that my existence could end at any moment at the speed of light because physics breaks.
Me: [does some research]
Me: Okay, I’m reassured. False vacuum is kind of like an octogenarian’s testicle: if nothing has caused it to drop by now, it probably isn’t going to. Black holes are pretty damn extreme. We can “see” them (until recently, just their effects). Which means their light and gravity has reached us. Which means they didn’t cause false vacuum decay. Which means they probably won’t. Cool. We’re probably safe. Furthermore, I can’t think of anything worse than false vacuum decay besides maximum entropy. I already know about that, so I’ve successfully grappled with the emotional implications of the worst possible existential sudden-death scenario. Nice.

Now by no means am I a scientist, I took chem last year and I’m taking physics this year, but I do consider myself to have a supple understanding of atoms and matter. I’d love some feedback because I think I might be confused here.

What you’re saying is basically that there are different types of quarks and larks, but since they are so small we can’t identify them all, although we know the up and down ones are there. Theoretically, couldn’t strange matter be recreated in a small chamber with some matter and a whole bunch of energy thrown at it? I get it’s inefficient, but the pressure the chamber would provide against the growing mass, and soon we would get strange matter. Secondly, you are saying that with the addition of energy, quarks and larks create more of themselves, which means energy is turned into matter, which isn’t possible as far as I know?

Now in terms of chemistry, we know atoms with 8 valent electrons are stable. Typically, with much more electrons and protons we get the result of complex atoms like radioactive isotopes. Strange matter Is supposedly the most stable harnessing strange quarks? I’m guessing that it’s not as apocalyptic as it’s being made out to be, since atoms act with less stable ones, like fluorine and hydrogen, to create stability. Stable atoms are pretty much docile. If strange matter acts like a neutron, it should just be a heavier neutron right? It would just mean that instead of a neutron, this would be a heavier substitute. strange matter flying around makes sense because some atoms don’t need 1 strange matter instead of their neutrons because it would take a lot of energy to do that. Where is it gonna become like A fire and infect everything?there aren’t any properties that suggest that all atoms need it naturally.

Finally, if atoms did need it and it spread, all the matter in space or in other planets would be strange. The Big Bang happened so long ago. Why didn’t strange matter intervene then? Why didn’t it infect everything. If strangelets are flying around for all those years, isn’t something bound to hit a large mass like a planet or an asteroid and we would be able to see it?

Im sorry guys, but perhaps this hyphotesis are not more than bullshit, so calm down.

It's interesting, but it seems like a huge stretch to say that a form of matter that can only form under ridiculous gravitational pressure and force would be able to survive in an environment with no such pressure. It might be the ideal configuration within the conditions of a neutron star, but remove it from that hypergravity and I would absolutely expect it to explode back into normal quarks.


There might be a lot of research supporting the hypothetical possibility of stable strange matter, but I would also consider it somewhat outside of testable for the time being; as for making it into another world-ender, has strange matter ever actually been interacted with? If we don't even know of any stars/planets/galaxies being eaten by strange matter, it seems like a stretch to consider it an existential threat to the universe as we know it.


I'm sure the research y'all cited is very good, very thorough, and very plausible... it just is so far outside the realm of normal that our understandings, and our capabilities to build realistic models of the universe with severely limited testing (or even detecting) of the matter in question doesn't suggest a conclusive answer here.

One major problem with chaining these hypotheses together is that 1) if the Big Bang made strange matter while everything was still a quark soup, 2) if strange matter is the most ground state, stable form of matter (so Gibbs free energy is pushing towards it spontaneously), and 3) if it can infect other matter and turn it strange like itself, then why wasn't the whole universe converted into strange matter? Why isn't that how it all turned out to begin with? Forget about the missing antimatter, or how the Standard Model disagrees with our ideas of the Big Bang (which is why we are looking for things like Strings and Branes to replace it with, unsuccessfully so far); if strange matter had all these properties, or even just two of the three, that should be all the universe is. So, given we exist, likely our understanding of strange matter, like our understanding of the Standard Model, must be flawed in some fundamental way. It's nice to talk and dream about though.

The main question I have is if strange matter is stable at lower pressures and also infectious then why wouldn’t the outer layers of neutron stars convert entirely into strange matter extremely quickly? And spinning neutron stars eject matter at their poles in jets as pulsars or magnetars so if the entire star was made of strange matter then it seems like we would have been able to detect that in the spectrum of their jets.

Also a quick search came up with some recent analyses that indicate that strange matter in neutron stars probably isn’t a thing, instead the core is probably simply stable pairs of up and down quarks. This would make sense in that the LHC and cosmic rays already provide the energies we think would be enough to create free floating quarks and strangelets but to date cosmic rays haven’t destroyed the Earth by creating infectious strangelets. So it does seem like free floating strangelets probably either aren’t a physical reality or aren’t infectious. That being said though the idea that dark matter might be non-infectious strange matter from the early universe and neutron stars is kind of cool. 🙂

We've yet to discover a single strange star, I don't think there's much out there. Or it's so dense that all of it gets sucked into the ensuing singularity that neutron star collisions always make.

The whole theory here is that strange matter can exist outside of a neutron star. Thankfully, I'm pretty certain that it cannot. If you look at literally any other experiments involving the creation of particles containing strange quarks, almost always they decay instantaneously into "up" and "down" quarks just as you stated near the beginning. If a strangelet did exit a neutron star, it wouldn't have the same environment that kept it stable, and it would spontaneously decay into normal matter again, much like how pressurised liquid oxygen becomes oxygen again once the pressure is released, but on the subatomic scale. I'm not saying that it is outright impossible, but given current experiments into strange quarks in matter, it is HIGHLY unlikely that any strange matter could survive outside a neutron star
